abstract.text: Colliders, among the most successful tools of particle physics, have revealed much about matter.
This review describes how colliders contribute to the search for particle dark matter, focusing on the highestenergy collider currently in operation, the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN.

In the absence of hints about the character of interactions between dark matter and standard matter, this review emphasizes what could be observed in the near future, presents the main experimental challenges, and discusses how collider searches fit into the broader field of dark matter searches.
Finally, it highlights a few areas to watch for the future LHC program.

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION
Cosmological observations of dark matter (DM) are perhaps the most persuasive experimental evidence for physics beyond the Standard Model (BSM) of particle physics.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: DM may not be composed of particles at all, but the Standard Model of particle physics in describing ordinary matter gives us a strong reason to consider a particle description of DM as well.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Neverthless, the evidence for DM (described in, e.g., Reference 1), is inconsistent with the properties of any known particle.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: While DM has gravitational interactions with normal matter, DM particles are dark (see the sidebar titled Particle Properties of Dark Matter); nongravitational interactions of DM must be relatively rare.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: DM is very stable, with a lifetime comparable to that of the Universe (e.g., 2).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: It is also nonrelativistic and collisionless.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: But most striking is its abundance at the present day [relic abundance (3)], extracted from measurements of the cosmic microwave background (4).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: There is approximately five times as much DM as the matter described by the Standard Model.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This fact provides one of the few quantitative clues about BSM physics, and suggests that the complexity of the DM particle sector could match or exceed that of ordinary matter.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Particle physicists are increasingly keen to understand what DM is, if it is indeed composed of particles.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Some experimenters, using direct detection (DD) experiments, look for Galactic DM colliding with underground targets made of ordinary matter (5).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Others, using indirect detection (ID) experiments, search for the products of annihilating DM concentrated within the gravitational potential wells of the Milky Way and elsewhere (6).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: If the only interaction between DM and ordinary matter is gravitational, these experiments may never observe it directly.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: To succeed, both types of searches require that DM interact with ordinary matter in some way: DM-nucleon (or DM-electron) interactions in DD searches or DM annihilation to Standard Model particles in ID searches.

body_text.section: PARTICLE PROPERTIES OF DARK MATTER

body_text.text: If DM can be produced at colliders, they will likely remain one of our preferred tools for learning more about it, regardless of where DM particles are first discovered.
body_text.section: PARTICLE PROPERTIES OF DARK MATTER

When the collision energy is near or higher than the mediator mass, complementary avenues to study the mediating interaction develop, analogous to the transition from the Fermi model of weak interactions at low energies to the Standard Model at higher energies.
body_text.section: Simplified models.

body_text.text: For example, at the LHC, a heavy neutral Z mediator would often decay into the partons that produced it, and fully reconstructing such visible decays could provide more information about the interaction than the invisible decays alone.
body_text.section: Simplified models.

body_text.text: One can construct simple descriptions of collider phenomenology without including the details of additional physics at energies higher than the collider scales, and therefore not relevant at the LHC.
body_text.section: Simplified models.

body_text.text: These descriptions are termed simplified models (e.g., 27,28), and can be considered an intermediate step the between simplest portal models and full theories.
body_text.section: Simplified models.

body_text.text: Under the assumption that only a few new particles will be important in the early phase of discovery, simplified models can be developed for tree-level pair production of invisible particles.

body_text.text: The set of such models currently employed for ATLAS and CMS searches is described in Reference 16, which builds upon much research from the wider DM community (e.g., 22,29,30).
body_text.section: Simplified models.

body_text.text: Although these simplified models often have to be embedded in a larger theory to satisfy theory constraints (31), in many cases they are sufficient to describe the leading-order collider phenomenology.
body_text.section: Simplified models.

Simplified models capture the typical features found in many models.

body_text.text: As such, they can guide the design of generic searches, but may fail to describe the full complexity of possible collider signatures that arise in more complete models.
body_text.section: Less-simplified models.

body_text.text: By contrast, relying too heavily on a small sample of complete models risks focusing searches too narrowly on an unrepresentative set of signatures.
body_text.section: Less-simplified models.

body_text.text: To solve this problem, many "less-simplified" models explore features that arise in special classes of models, finding a middle ground between too simplistic and unnecessarily complex.
body_text.section: Less-simplified models.

body_text.text: Because the set of such models grows quickly with the number of components, and because there is no broad consensus on which models should be a priority, very few of them have been explicitly considered by LHC searches.

body_text.text: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories
So far, we have considered rather general simplified models inspired by the electroweak sector of the Standard Model.
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: Obviously, there are many more possibilities.
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: Additional sources of inspiration for searches are the large number of BSM theories that have been developed to solve theoretical problems of the Standard Model as well as the mechanisms through which these provide invisible particles.
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: SUSY is one such class of theories, postulating partner particles to all Standard Model degrees of freedom.
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: Supersymmetric models can stabilize the mass of the light Higgs boson and introduce desired features in the Standard Model, such as coupling unification.

body_text.text: Reviews of supersymmetric DM models can be found elsewhere (57).
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: Here, we broadly sketch models relevant to recent experimental progress and emphasize areas where we expect future developments.
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: Supersymmetric DM, the archetype for the concept of weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs), has a long history (58).
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: The most viable and well-studied type of supersymmetric DM has been neutralino DM.
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: The neutralino, a partner particle to the Standard Model gauge bosons, is often assumed to be the lightest supersymmetric particle (LSP).

body_text.text: In the MSSM, there are four neutralinos, each of which is a mixture of Standard Model boson superpartners: a wino, a bino, and two higgsino fermion states.

body_text.text: Such models are used as predictive benchmarks for DM searches.

body_text.text: One such model is the phenomenological MSSM (pMSSM), which assumes no sources of CP violation beyond the Standard Model and no flavor-changing neutral currents, and retains universal couplings and masses for first-and second-generation superpartners, reducing the number of MSSM parameters to 19.
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: Another DM candidate, found in gauge-or gravity-mediated supersymmetric models, is the gravitino, a spin-3/2 particle superpartner of the graviton.
body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: Gravitino interactions are suppressed by the Planck scale (10 18 GeV) before SUSY breaking.

body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.section: Supersymmetric Models and Other Complete Theories

body_text.text: Long-Lived Particle Models
Another class of models, found within and beyond SUSY, feature suppressed cascade decays of a heavier particle (the NLSP in SUSY) to a lighter particle (the DM LSP in SUSY).
body_text.section: Long-Lived Particle Models

body_text.text: The suppression can be so large that the particle travels a macroscopic length within the detector before it decays.
body_text.section: Long-Lived Particle Models

body_text.text: Such particles are known as long-lived particles (LLPs).
body_text.section: Long-Lived Particle Models

body_text.text: LHC detectors are not optimized for this purpose, and additional work is required for searches to be sensitive.
body_text.section: Long-Lived Particle Models

body_text.text: For example, within SUSY one way to suppress decays is for the NLSP to decay through a heavy intermediary.
body_text.section: Long-Lived Particle Models

body_text.text: Split SUSY models are a subset of SUSY models in which the gluino must decay through a heavy, off-shell squark (61).
body_text.section: Long-Lived Particle Models

body_text.section: Long-Lived Particle Models

body_text.section: Long-Lived Particle Models

body_text.text: Another way to achieve long-lived decays is with parametrically small couplings, as in the case of gauge-mediated SUSY models wherein the long-lived NLSP decays to its Standard Model partner plus the gravitino (60), in a SUSY analog of Cabibbo-suppressed B meson decays in the Standard Model.

body_text.text: Because of the prevalence of these mechanisms, it is important to look for long-lived cascade decays.

The interactions described in the previous section have many consequences for astrophysics (where they could modify the DM density) and for noncollider and collider particle physics experiments.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS

body_text.text: Collisions of known particles at high energy, observed with well-understood detectors, have led to the discovery of many of the fundamental components of known matter in the Standard Model.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS

body_text.text: While collider experiments alone cannot discover DM, they can discover the existence of invisible particles, which could lead the way to direct study of DM-Standard Model matter mediators in other channels and of additional particles in a dark sector.

body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS

body_text.text: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

So far motivated by simple models, the X + / E T experimental searches discussed make few choices about the visible recoil particles (i.e., the species of a single particle), yet they have already led to a plethora of diverse signatures.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: Models with more degrees of freedom vastly expand the set of signatures to be explored.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: SUSY adds, along with invisible particles, a full copy of the Standard Model particle spectrum to be discovered.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: Each superpartner features particular decay chains that can be targeted to a greater or lesser degree, privileging either generality or maximal sensitivity.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: Compared with the searches described above, SUSY searches generally opt for a more specific decay topology and thus apply more stringent event selections based on the expected kinematic features, often using discriminating variables based on the combined mass of visible and invisible particles (e.g., 122) to recover the ability to resolve various resonant decays.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: SUSY has received much attention from ATLAS and CMS, and many searches for its particles, such as for squarks and gluinos, have a long history at earlier colliders as well.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: In this section, we discuss experimental results with explicit connections to DM.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: So far, no SUSY search has produced a conclusive signal.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: However, given its multifarious signatures, it is difficult to make general statements about the current status, even for simplified models of SUSY.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: Perhaps the best one can say is that searches for strongly produced superpartners constrain them for masses approaching ∼2 TeV for neutralino masses up to 1 TeV (e.g., 123,124); by contrast, other processes are less constrained.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: Direct production of weakly coupled superpartners has a much smaller production rate; therefore, the constraints on them are significantly weaker, as shown in Figure 5.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: Third-generation squarks are generally only constrained to be at least several hundred GeV for neutralinos of similar masses (e.g., 125,126).
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: But there are numerous exceptions to these blanket statements, even before one takes into account that the masses exclusions shown in Figure 5 apply only to specific slices of a multidimensional model parameter space.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: Although LHC searches have so far probed mainly SUSY channels that are strongly produced, searches for more rare processes are now entering their prime.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: With the data now collected, one can explore the electroweakino parameter space (e.g., 127, 128).
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: Searches for gauge boson superpartners (gauginos) can reach approximately 1 TeV if the superpartners of Standard Model leptons are light, and the search can benefit from a high leptonic branching ratio, whereas their reach is lower if their decays proceed through W and Z bosons.
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: More luminosity also provides access to new regions of parameter space for specific signatures, such as so-called compressed regions where small mass differences between superpartners cause the signals to lie buried in large backgrounds at low / E T (129,130).

body_text.text: Small mass differences can also suppress superpartner decays, resulting in long lifetimes that can be exploited to study regions with a mass difference as low as 0.2 GeV for higgsino models (131).

body_text.text: Other mechanisms of decay suppression can do this as well [e.g., split SUSY (132)].
body_text.section: Searches for Supersymmetric Invisible Particles

body_text.text: Despite the unwieldy diversity SUSY signatures, a sufficiently specific model can provide a concrete framework on which to build an understanding of the combined effect of many experimental constraints.

body_text.text: The study reported in Reference 133, continued by the LHC experimental collaborations (134, 135), uses the pMSSM to define a finite (although large) parameter space for which the wealth of experimental constraints can be systematically evaluated, and underexamined signatures can be considered for future emphasis.

body_text.text: Searches for Long-Lived Particles
Prompt decays produce a visible recoil that originates at the collision point; thus, it can be reconstructed using the techniques for which the experiments were designed.
body_text.section: Searches for Long-Lived Particles

body_text.text: The longlived mediators described in Section 2.4 present different experimental challenges.
body_text.section: Searches for Long-Lived Particles

body_text.text: For short lifetimes, LLPs can decay inside the tracking detectors, appearing as displaced decay vertices.
body_text.section: Searches for Long-Lived Particles

body_text.text: Some SUSY decay chains lead to disappearing tracks, if the visible particles decay into the LSP and soft particles (e.g., 138, 139).

body_text.text: Relic Density Considerations

In the absence of a signal in noncollider experiments, the ability of a model to link its invisible particles with the observed DM abundance is key to distinguishing it from other types of models of BSM physics.
body_text.section: Relic Density Considerations

body_text.text: Making this link, however, requires extrapolating from the present day to the early Universe along an increasingly tenuous chain of assumptions.
body_text.section: Relic Density Considerations

body_text.text: For simplified models, this is especially problematic, because the model is designed to describe collider-scale processes; it may not even contain higher-scale interactions relevant in the early Universe.
body_text.section: Relic Density Considerations

body_text.text: Nevertheless, it is interesting to examine the parameter regions in models that can make the link, even if in limited situations (182,183).

body_text.text: For example, for the general simplified models discussed in Section 2.2.2, one can use programs such as MadDM and Mi-crOMEGas (163,184) to compute the DM abundance for a standard thermal relic, assuming that the interaction described by the simplified model is the one responsible for setting the relic density.

body_text.text: Often (e.g., Figure 7), ATLAS and CMS supplement their results with contours indicating where within a model this procedure obtains the correct DM density of ωc = 0.12h 2 .

body_text.text: OUTLOOK

We are optimistic that, in the next decade, the variety of powerful searches for particle DM, from collider approaches to underground experiments to observatories, will lead to much progress toward its eventual discovery.
body_text.section: OUTLOOK

body_text.text: Collider strategies that have been essential to discover and understand the fundamental particles of the Standard Model are being extended with new techniques designed to extract rare and difficult signals from the data.
body_text.section: OUTLOOK

body_text.text: Our understanding of collider search targets is also rapidly improving.
body_text.section: OUTLOOK

body_text.text: Along with SUSY benchmarks motivated by the hierarchy problem, targets directly motivated by DM observations are encouraging a new generation of experimentalists to branch out into directions that so far have been only sparsely explored.
body_text.section: OUTLOOK

body_text.text: Finally, the HL-LHC data set will exceed that presented here by a factor of 100.
body_text.section: OUTLOOK

body_text.text: FUTURE ISSUES
1. The obvious directions for LHC searches are toward lower-rate processes and processes that are more difficult to detect:
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: • Extended scalar sectors and electroweak SUSY are among the possible benchmarks for lower rate processes.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: As the LHC experiments record progressively more data during Run 2 and Run 3, searches are becoming sensitive to the simplest scalar simplified models, opening the door to more realistic models.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: On a longer timescale, the HL-LHC data set will bring sensitivity up to 3 TeV in scalar mediator masses for unit couplings (186) and precision knowledge of the Standard Model Higgs sector, and the mass reach for electroweak production of SUSY partners should increase by a few hundred GeV (187).
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: • With data arriving at a slightly less frantic pace, experimentally challenging LLP signatures are a growing field, and benchmarks similar to Reference 16 are needed to help guide the design of these searches.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: Among many ongoing efforts are the bottom-up approach adopted in Reference 188, which connects such models with the LLP limit of those described in Section 2.2.2.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: Many LLP searches have not yet been done, and not all existing searches have been optimized.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: Therefore, LLP searches have the potential for substantial improvements, much beyond those expected by the accumulation of luminosity.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: 2. Precision searches, detector upgrades, and efficient triggering of rare signals buried in large backgrounds are key to fully exploiting the HL-LHC data set:
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: • In the familiar jet+ / E T search, precision estimates of the V +jet backgrounds, and of the inputs to these predictions, will be crucial.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: Efforts in that direction are ongoing (189).
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: • Upgrades for Run 3 and HL-LHC provide new capabilities that may make new data more valuable for these searches than what recorded so far for rare processes involving light new particles.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: This is a subject that has been largely unexplored for ATLAS and CMS (190) and that can be developed further when tracking information is available at the trigger level to remove pileup.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: LHCb will make use of a novel triggerless detector readout to perform dark photon searches with unprecedented sensitivities (191).
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: 3. Future hadron and electron-positron colliders have immense potential [see, e.g., studies on a future hadron collider (192)].
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: Nevertheless, present studies largely continue the approaches already in use at the LHC.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: A new hadron collider would be built to discover New Physics; therefore, qualitatively different experimental design, benchmark models, and analysis strategies should be considered.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: 4. More useful working comparisons between results from colliders, underground searches, and observatories should take into account the uncertainties on each type of result, and on the extrapolations between them.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: The main uncertainties for LHC searches are outlined in Section 3 and in the experimental references; for a summary of DD and ID uncertainties, see References 193 and 194 and references therein.
body_text.section: FUTURE ISSUES

body_text.text: 5. Comparisons among collider and noncollider particle physics experiments are becoming standard; relating particle physics to astrophysical observables is crucial to exploit the few clues that DM can provide about BSM particle physics.

body_text.text: We strongly encourage further research on this subject (e.g., 195).
